intro: Phloeophila yupanki, commonly known as the Andean phloeophila, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Andes. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy, herbaceous stems and showy, five-petaled flowers that bloom in shades of pink and white. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often covered in fine pubescence. Phloeophila yupanki is adapted to cold, arid environments and plays a role in local ecosystems by providing habitat and nectar for pollinators.
